update.description:
This patch creates two new member variables in the LogPlay class to keep track of the start and stop times of a log episode. Additionally, it will create two new accessors for exposing the log file name and file size. In the near future, log name, log size and start/stop time will be used by the GUI playback tool.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.

I'll submit a new pull request with some unit tests for this class.

pull_request.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

pullrequest.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

content.raw:
How about a function that returns the whole path? Currently Gazebo always saves the logs at `~/.gazebo/log/<date and time>/gzserver/state.log`, so this function is always returning just `state.log`. 

I'm not sure if it would be more useful to have a separate function for the path and keep this one for the name or just have one for the full path, what do you think?
content.html:
How about a function that returns the whole path? Currently Gazebo always saves the logs at ~/.gazebo/log/<date and time>/gzserver/state.log, so this function is always returning just state.log.

I'm not sure if it would be more useful to have a separate function for the path and keep this one for the name or just have one for the full path, what do you think?

update.description:
This patch creates two new member variables in the LogPlay class to keep track of the start and stop times of a log episode. In the near future, this will be used by the GUI playback tool to display a label with the duration of the log or/and the start/end times.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.

update.description:
This patch creates two new member variables in the LogPlay class to keep track of the start and stop times of a log episode. In the near future, this will be used by the GUI playback tool to display a label with the duration of the log or/and the start/end times.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.
update.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

pull_request.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

update.description:
This patch adds the start and stop time to the header of a log file. In the near future, this will be used by the GUI playback tool to display a label with the duration of the log or/and the start/end times.

Note that the header has been moved from the beginning of the file to the end. It's more convenient at the end because when we start writing the log file we don't know the stop time yet.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.
update.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

pull_request.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.

pull_request.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

pullrequest.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

content.raw:
I'm not sure what's the usual procedure in these cases, but here, if you play an old log file you get two errors:

~~~
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:134] Log file header is missing the log start time.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:144] Log file header is missing the log end time.
~~~

To me, it feels like it should be some warning somehow about the log version instead of an error. In fact, maybe we should change the log version from 1.0 to 2.0 since by the time gazebo 6 comes out, the files will have very different structures?
content.html:
I'm not sure what's the usual procedure in these cases, but here, if you play an old log file you get two errors:

[Err] [LogPlay.cc:134] Log file header is missing the log start time.
[Err] [LogPlay.cc:144] Log file header is missing the log end time.

To me, it feels like it should be some warning somehow about the log version instead of an error. In fact, maybe we should change the log version from 1.0 to 2.0 since by the time gazebo 6 comes out, the files will have very different structures?

pull_request.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

update.description:
This patch adds the start and stop time to the header of a log file. In the near future, this will be used by the GUI playback tool to display a label with the duration of the log or/and the start/end times.

Note that the header has been moved from the beginning of the file to the end. It's more convenient at the end because when we start writing the log file we don't know the stop time yet.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.
update.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files
